title: 109_hr4924
content: The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Tribute to Dr. Norman E. Borlaug Act of 2006". Dr. Norman E. Borlaug, born in Iowa and educated at the University of Minnesota, is a renowned figure in world agriculture. He has made significant contributions to humanity and currently resides in Texas, where he is a faculty member at Texas A&M University and serves as President of the Sasakawa Africa Association. Borlaug's groundbreaking work in rural Mexico after World War II has brought about radical changes in agriculture. Dr. Borlaug developed a high-yield strain of wheat that resisted disease, leading to the "green revolution" that helped rural poor in Mexico and prevented famine in India and Pakistan. His methods spread to the Middle East and rice production, saving over a billion lives. He received the Nobel Prize in 1970 for his agricultural work. Dr. Borlaug, a Nobel Prize recipient, has received various honors and awards for his work in agriculture. At 91 years old, he continues to work on alleviating poverty and malnutrition, serving as president of the Sasakawa Global 2000 Africa Project. He also remains Chairman of the Council of Advisors of the World Food Prize, an organization he founded in 1986. Dr. Borlaug, a Nobel Prize recipient, has saved countless lives through his groundbreaking achievements in agriculture. He is deserving of America's highest civilian award, the congressional gold medal, for his lifetime of work. The World Food Prize has honored Laureates from various countries, recognizing exceptional achievements similar to Dr. Borlaug's. Dr. Norman E. Borlaug, a Nobel Prize recipient for his groundbreaking achievements in agriculture, is set to receive a congressional gold medal in recognition of his enduring contributions to the United States and the world. The medal will be presented by the President Pro Tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, with the design and striking to be determined by the Secretary of the Treasury. Additionally, duplicate medals may be authorized. The Secretary may strike and sell duplicates of the gold medal at a price covering costs. The medal is considered a national medal and duplicates are numismatic items. Proceeds from sales can be used as authorized. SEC. 6. AUTHORITY TO USE FUND AMOUNTS; PROCEEDS OF SALE. Authorized charges against the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund for medal costs. Sale proceeds of duplicate bronze medals deposited in the Fund.
